bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 29, 1875

div1.p: Reed reaffirms his feelings for Emilie Lawrence. He describes the physician's lot, and inquires about the new Murfreesboro newspaper and their friends Miss Peace and Mr. Sharpe.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 29, 1875
div1.p:
The dear,
little message that I had been
expecting since Monday came
safely into my hands, this
morning, and dispelled my anx-
iety- I had begun to fear that
you were sick, but since I
find that you have recovered
your health and strength suf-
ficiently to assist at a Christ-
mas Tree, I am so much re-
lieved and rejoiced that I can
afford to wait 2 or 3 days for
my letter. Bless your little
heart! I forgive you? That
I will with all my heart!
and will tell you that you
are the dearest, sweetest
girl alive! Ain't it so? If you don't agree
with me, I am very sorry, but nevertheless,
I will remain of the same opinion still-
All of your work came during Christmas,
but mine has come since & for the past 2
days has kept me as busy as a bee- Don't get
frightened when I tell you that we have
two cases of Small-Pox on the Post-- Besides
these, there are some few sick children that
I must attend to-- Oh! the responsibility of
a physician! Did you ever think of it, my
darling E.? And though you have, you
can form no idea of the anxiety, the gnawing
anxiety, that burdens a physician's mind!
I sometimes wonder why this did not
occur to me when I first began my
Profession (but then I was a boy & did not
trouble my mind with thinking) yet
had I then known what I now know, med-
icine would have been my last choice.
Not that I do not like my profession; far
from that- But, Oh! to stand by, as it were,
with your hands tied, unable to render
any assistance, & with anxious parents
& friends begging you to stay the destroy-
er; this is well nigh unendurable!
I am afraid that I am too sympathetic,
but Heaven knows such is my nature;
and I cannot be otherwise- I had rather
err on the side of sympathy than to have
none at all- I did not intend to say so
much on the subject when I began, & must
beg your pardon- You did not say whether
the volume had arrived or not- I do trust that
it was not delayed in any way, & yet it would
be just my fortune- Please, when you next
write, just mention whether you have received
it or not. so that if not, I may make some in-
quiry about it- I trust, however, that it has
come to hand e're this, and
you have been enabled
to pass an hour pleasant-
ly over its pages- In a
former letter, I said that I
had some questions to ask
concerning dear old Mur-
freesboro- You don't get mad
because I call it old, do
you? I am sure, my dar-
ling, that it is beautiful
in its old age, & that it is
each year becoming more
charming- When I say “old”,
I mean somewhere between
1 and 100- Isn't there latitude
enough? I would say the
same concerning myself-
Well, I want to know what
has become of that wonder-
ful newspaper that was
to flood the land with
intelligence, & make Hert-
ford (I believe that is the
county) blossom like the
rose! I would put the last
four words in quotation
marks, but I don't know wheth-
er I have quoted them cor-
rectly or not- Indeed, my dar-
ling u, if you will permit me to
to fly off at a tangent, I'll
tell you, that I have, recently,
so deserted the poets, that
I would hesitate to attempt
any quotation (provided any
poet ever made use of the
said words, which I think is
far from probable.) To re-
turn- Has the paper been star-
ted into life? I should think
that with two such large
editors it ought to suc-
ceed- If it has not been
“gathered in” before I come
down, I think I will have to sub-
scribe for a copy-

In the next place, I desire to
know whether you have yet
made the acquaintance of my old friend (and here I
mean old) Miss, Bert Peace?
My sister writes me that
Miss Peace is very much
pleased with Murfreesboro,
and I am sure, if when she makes
your acquaintance, my little
Sweetheart, she will be more
than charmed-, & until she
does form your acquaintance,
she will have neglected the
greatest attraction that
the town possesses.

Do you ever catch a glympse
of my friend Sharpe, or does
he stay in his shell so
close that he is not
at all visible? You must
remember that I left you
under his special care-
You were not aware, per-
haps, that you were provi-
ded with so watchful and
gallant a protector-!

There are other questions yet
to be propounded, but as my paper
is almost exhausted, I will post-
pone those to another time-
div1.closer:
Believe me, as ever,
your own fond &
devoted Walter.
